did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.corpname:
Marist College
Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: Published in 2017, The Voice of America: Lowell Thomas and the Invention of 20th Century Journalism by Mitchell Stephens is the first completed biography ever written on Lowell Thomas, an innovative journalist of the 20th century. The Mitchell Stephens Papers Collection includes research materials and drafts for the biography.
did.physloc: Please contact the Marist College Archives and Special Collections for information regarding use and access of this collection.

acqinfo.head: Acquisitions Information
acqinfo.p: Collection was donated to Marist College Archives and Special Collections by Mitchell Stephens on December 1, 2022.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions to Access
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection.

phystech.head: Physical Access Restriction
phystech.p: Collection contains digital materials on a USB external hard drive which must be accessed with a computer.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Mitchell Stephens was born on August 16, 1949 in New York City. Stephens is a NYU Professor of Journalism and Mass Communication and author of numerous articles and 8 books including The New York Times "Notable Book of the Year,” A History of News. Before working on The Voice of America, Mitchell Stephens was interviewed by director Richard Moulton on a documentary he was doing on Lowell Thomas. Mitchell Stephens would work with Moulton again on the documentary Voice of America: Lowell Thomas and the Rise of Broadcast News (2019) in which Anne T. Donaghy, the granddaughter of Lowell Thomas, was an executive producer. While conducting projects with Richard Moulton, Mitchell Stephens began researching and writing The Voice of America. Stephens began researching and drafting the Lowell Thomas biography in 2014. While researching for the Lowell Thomas biography, Mitchell Stephens traveled to Ohio, Colorado, Yukon, Alaska and many of the same places Lowell Thomas visited and reported. Although Stephens did not read the manuscript drafts, he would consult the outline of the unfinished Lowell Thomas biography by Fred Crawford as the basis for his own book. Stephens would also consult many original materials including journals, travelogues, correspondences, photographs, and footage within the Lowell Thomas Collection at the Archives and Special Collections at Marist College.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: These records are organized into 6 series: 1) Manuscript Drafts, 2) Research Materials, 2.1) Chapter 1. A Portrait of the Journalist as a Young Cowboy, 2.2) Chapter 2. Two Scoops in Chicago, 2.3) Chapter 3. See America First, 2.4) Chapter 4. Too Good to Be True 2.5) Chapter 5. Something More Colossal Than Anything of its Kind Ever Tried, 2.6) Chapter 6. A Blue-Eyed, Beardless Man in Arab Robes, 2.7) Chapter 7. Come with Me to the Land of History, Mystery and Romance, 2.8) Chapter 8. How Dull It Is to Pause 2.9) Chapter 9. Having the Ear of America, 2.10) Chapter 10. The Voice of God, 2.11) Chapter 11. Catching Up with the War, 2.12) Chapter 12. The Very Roof of the World, 2.13) Chapter 13. An Entirely New Form of Entertainment, 2.15) Chapter 14. To Strive, To Seek, To Find and Not to Yield, 2.15) Additional Materials, 3) Correspondence, 4) Maps, 5) Photographs, 6) Digital Materials, 6.1) Manuscripts and Research Materials, 6.2) Lowell Thomas Photographs from Richard Moulton.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials created or saved by Mitchell Stephens, including his manuscript drafts and notes for The Voice of America: Lowell Thomas and the Invention of 20th Century Journalism, as well as articles on journalism and communication. Much of the collection consists of copies from the Lowell Thomas Collection at Marist College that have been annotated by Stephens. The collection also includes correspondence between Stephens and Richard Moulton and Anne T. Donaghy.
Series contains chapter drafts, notes, and corrections of the The Voice of America: Lowell Thomas and the Invention of the 20th- Century Journalism.

arrangement.p: Each chapter draft has been placed in its own folder and organized by the order of chapters as it appears in the book then chronologically by date. Discarded chapters or those with different titles are placed at the end. The folder titles correspond with the headers of each document which have the chapter number and title. Sometimes the chapter numbers change between drafts. The series also contains fact checks and corrections of chapters. The three notebooks are titled by the style and brand of the book as they were not given a title by Mitchell Stephens.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of 15 subseries pertaining to materials used for research on Lowell Thomas. The first 14 subseries coincide with the 14 chapters of the Lowell Thomas biography, The Voice of America: Lowell Thomas and the Invention of 20th Century Journalism. The last subseries consists of new research materials. Many of the materials are copies of Lowell Thomas’ journals, letters, travelogues, and articles.

arrangement.p: The subseries are arranged by chapter titles in the order they appear in The Voice of America: Lowell Thomas and the Invention of 20th Century Journalism and the folders are arranged alphabetically. Original folder titles were kept. Items should be kept in orginal order as some pages are double sided with Stephen’s original work being front facing.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.1: Chapter 1. A Portrait of the Journalist as a Young Cowboy

scopecontent.p: Subseries includes research materials on Lowell Thomas’ early life including information on his family and where he grew up in Victor, Colorado such as copies of: Dr. Harry G. Thomas, “Cripple Creek at the Turn of the Century,” a chapter of an unfinished memoir by Lowell Thomas’ father and a transcript of a 1951 interview between Dr. Harry Thomas and Dick Roelofs; and 1997 Victor Elks Lodge #367 100th Anniversary book. Subseries includes History of Colorado, The Victor Record 1910-1911 on microfilm.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.2: Chapter 2. Two Scoops in Chicago

scopecontent.p: Series contains research on Chicago in 1915 including copies of letters between Lowell Thomas and his parents between 1915 – 1916; and copies of Lowell Thomas’ journal from 1915.

Series contains annotated copies of Lowell Thomas’ correspondence with his wife Frances Thomas and copies of Thomas’ journal during his early trips to Alaska. Also contains articles Stephens used as background information on Alaska.

did.unittitle: Letters to Fran - Alaska II - Princeton
Letters to Fran - Alaska II - Princeton
Letters to Fran - Alaska II - Princeton
Letters to Fran - Alaska II - Princeton
Letters to Fran - Alaska II - Princeton
Subseries 2.4: Chapter 4. Too Good to Be True

scopecontent.p: Series contains Includes annotated copies of Lowell Thomas’ journal and travelogue from 1916 to the beginning of World War I.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.5: Chapter 5. Something More Colossal Than Anything of its Kind Ever Tried (WWI)

scopecontent.p: Series contains annotated copies of Lowell Thomas’ travelogue and journal before World War I and copies of articles on WWI and Harry Chase.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.6: Chapter 6. A Blue-Eyed, Beardless Man in Arab Robes (Middle East and WWI)

scopecontent.p: Series contains copies of Lowell Thomas’ field journals of Arabia and the Middle East. Many of the research materials in this subseries are related to series 2.7: Chapter 7. Come with Me to the Land of History, Mystery and Romance.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.7: Chapter 7. Come with Me to the Land of History, Mystery and Romance

scopecontent.p: Series contains materials on Lowell Thomas and T.E. Lawrence in the 1920s including copies of “With Allenby in Palestine.” There are also copies and criticisms of “The Show” and of Lawrence in Arabia.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.8: Chapter 8. How Dull It Is to Pause

scopecontent.p: Series contains information regarding the Fred Crawford papers at Marist College includes a copy of Crawfords list of Books by Lowell Thomas. Also included is a copy of Good Evening Everybody by Lowell Thomas.

did.unittitle: Chapter 9. Having the Ear of America

scopecontent.p: Series contains copies of articles on the history of early radio in the 1920s and 1930s, as well as annotated copies of Lowell Thomas’ scripts of radio shows.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.10: Chapter 10. The Voice of God

scopecontent.p: Series contains copies of newspaper articles on clubs Lowell Thomas was involved in during the 1930s and 40s. Also includes copies of articles on T.E. Lawrence’s death and broadcast in 1935. There are also copies of essays and articles on television and shows in the 1940s.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.11: Chapter 11. Catching Up with the War (WWII)

scopecontent.p: Series contains a 1936 Sunoco Oil Election Year Facts edited by Lowell Thomas, copies of essays on the Holocaust along with copies of Lowell Thomas’ journals and reports on World War II.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.12: Chapter 12. The Very Roof of the World

scopecontent.p: Series contains copies of articles and essays about the Dalai Lama of Tibet and the war against communism during the 1940s and 1950s which Lowell Thomas reported on.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.13: Chapter 13. An Entirely New Form of Entertainment

scopecontent.p: Series contains research on Cinerama and television, including Lowell Thomas’ High Adventure during the McCarthy era in the 1950s.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.14: Chapter 14. To Strive, To Seek, To Find, and Not to Yield

scopecontent.p: Series contains annotated copies of journal articles, newspaper articles, and obituaries regarding the last three decades of Lowell Thomas’ life from 1960s to 1981 and his legacy afterward. There is also a National Geographic reprint from July 1964 by Mrs. Lowell Thomas, JR. Also includes articles about the film, Lawrence of Arabia.
Series contains copies of Fred Crawford’s letters and outline of unfinished Lowell Thomas biography. Also included are copies of Lowell Thomas’ indentures and an untitled transcript.

did.unittitle: Untitled Transcript(Possibly Voice of America Documentary)

scopecontent.p: Series contains consists of correspondence between Mitchell Stephens and Richard Moulton, Anne T. Donaghy, and Quaker Hill Historical Society. Rick Moulton sent DVDs as well as a Flash Drive of Lowell Thomas Photos which have been copied and included in Series 6. Digital Materials.

did.unittitle: From Historical Society of Quaker Hill and Pawling
From Jesse White (Secretery of State of Illinois

scopecontent.p: Series contains large print photographs of Lowell Thomas.

Series contains maps of places Mitchell Stephens visited while conducting research. Maps are of: Skagway, Alaska; London; Cripple Creek and Victor, Colorado; Yukon, Canada. There are maps of the various gold mines in Colorado as well.
Series contains digital research materials and manuscripts created by Mitchell Stephens.

Series contains manuscript drafts of The Voice of America and articles Stephens wrote on Lowell Thomas and other topics such as journalism and fake news. Research materials include interviews with Anne Donaghy and saved copies of journal and newspaper articles regarding Lowell Thomas and the places and times associated with him. Many of these pieces were printed out and written on by Stephens and can be found in Series 2: Research Materials. Voice of America is a documentary Stephens wrote and was directed by Richard Moulton and came out in 2019.

arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically. Some of the folder time stamps changed during processing.

did.unittitle: Subseries 6.2: Lowell Thomas Photographs from Richard Moulton

scopecontent.p: Richard Moulton originally mailed these photographs of Lowell Thomas as a USB to Mitchell Stephens. They have now been copied and saved on a hard drive. Photographs include lantern slides of Lowell Thomas in Arabia, Egypt, Italy, Palestine, and London.
